reviewText: This show, during the first season was nothing short of spectacular.  The second season tries to pick up on the incredible emotion that ended the first season.  In the new season, Caesar (for fairly obvious reasons) is not the plot moving character, Mark Antony is.  Played by the fantastic James Purefoy, Antony is a tragically flawed, brutal character.  Vorenus also has become a much colder character.  Simon Woods takes over the role of Octavian mid-way through the season.  This happened to demonstrate time lapses, but that was the only slightly sub-par part of the series.  Max Pirkis was much better then Woods, but he is sufficient.  The second season is fantastic, and the only sad part is was that Caesar had to die (Ciaran Hinds was simply AMAZING in season 1).  James Purefoy alone makes the season worth buying.

Idiotic over-sped/simplified cookie-cutter cartoonish buffoonery full of plot holes and historic inaccuracies.

Let me give you an example:

I complained that HBO Romes portrayal of the Battle of Pharsalus as a 5-second blurry montage. Now, having seen season 2s portrayal of the Battle of Philippi, I only wish the latter was a blurry montage. I am trying to understand what was the thinking of whoever was in charge of producing that idiocy.

What happened in real life:

Battle day 1:

Mark Anthony + Octavian vs. Brutus + Cassius. The two forces arrange themselves in defensive positions and try to lure each other out of them. Not being idiots, each side refuses to be goaded. Then Mark Anthony attempts to secretly flank Cassius by moving his forces through a marsh. Cassius realizes too late, responds with too few forces, his army is destroyed.

Meanwhile, Brutuss troops are tired of his cautious approach. This attitude will bite him in the butt later, but today it wins him the battle. They decide to just wing it and storm Octavians position. Their unplanned attack catches Octavians forces by surprise, and they're destroyed. Octavian craps his pants while hiding in a swamp (true story).

So, technically its a draw. Except Cassius doesnt realize what happened on Brutuss side (that the latter won) and, thinking that Brutus was killed, commits suicide. Pretty much the rest of the history of the Western world is arguably strongly influenced by this one mistake.

What follows is 20 days during which Brutus builds fortifications making it impossible for Mark Anthony and Octavian to charge his position. Two sides maneuver against each other in positional warfare reminiscent of WWI (or US Civil War). Brutus's fleet intercepts Anthonys reinforcements and destroys them. MA and Octavian are about to starve.

But, the troops don't respect Brutus (the less respected commander comparing to the now-dead Cassius) and take his positional tactics for cowardice. They force him to charge Mark Anthonys lines, and his army is predictably destroyed. (The same happened to Pompey vs. Caesar btw.) He commits a suicide, and the Republic is dead with him. This is pretty similar to how Southern generals were mistrustful of Robert E. Lees and Longstreets positional warfare, eventually forcing them to commit Pickets Charge during the Battle of Gettysburg, losing the war.

I mean, this is an awesome battle. You have tactics, strategy, human emotion, chance and luck, etc. You can make a whole movie about it alone, like they did with Gettysburg.

HBO Romes version:

The two armies stupidly clash against each other, head-on. Chaos ensues. Mark Anthony is sitting on a horse eating a loaf of bread. Octavian asks: Whats going on? Anthony answers: No idea. Throws away bread and decides to charge with his cavalry, explaining: When in doubt, attack. Octavian doesnt want to charge, but, seeing his buddy Agrippas sour look, says, Whatever. Go ahead. Agrippa and two other horsemen (!) charge.

Meanwhile, Cassius is being pierced by arrows in a turtle formation. Then he decides for some reason to just charge a cloud of dust. He is brought, dying, to Brutus. When asked What happened, he says, You know, I am not sure, and dies. Brutus takes off his armor and charges against the attacking line of soldiers, being stabbed to death, Julius Caesarstyle.

Now, tell me: who came up with this idiocy? Showing *nothing* is better than showing this. Showing an excerpt from Shakespeares Julius Caesar would be better. Replacing the two sides with Japanese samurai and Vikings would be more realistic than what HBO came up with.

While it's no surprise that a made-for-HBO Television programme ramps up the frequent gratuitous violence and vigilante thug justice in a show, I was thinking it would have been just as easy for the same care to get historical details right in costuming and props (which is done pretty well here) would be applied to probable dialog and characters instead of the extreme liberties taken with made-up character traits of well known historical figures such as Attia, Octavian, and, Brutus. The tragedies and ironies of these Roman lives couldn't be better written in a fictional novel.  Of course, some details that were unknown were filled in by the shows writers. In Season 2 of the very-expensive, HBO/BBC TV series, "Rome", the producers continue to present their storylines set against the general historical backdrop of people, nations, major events, the culture, and architecture of the era. They present rivalries, friendships, internal intrigue, competing families, warring armies, and amorous relationships. The imaginatively-depicted, very carnal, capital city of Rome is the center piece location of the story although the storyline goes as far afield, location-wise, as Egypt, as expected. The costly mini-series ran for two seasons, was shot on an enormous series of sets, and was cancelled, although many fans wanted a third season. Season 1 was rumored to cost $100Million. The first three seasons shot were cut down to two, losing some historical flow, because of the historically knowledgeable British audience. Some shortcomings are: the actors are not too 'Roman' in appearance and the battles are certainly not epic, as the producers get right to the point of who won and who lost each battle and move quickly to the aftermaths.

In Season 1, it was Caesar versus Pompey as rivals for control of the Roman empire with a great deal of political maneuvering going on among the members of the Senate, the competing families, friends, enemies, soldiers, and citizens. Then at the end of S-1, Caesar is murdered in the Senate by Brutus and cohorts. The trials, tribulations, and complex friendship of two fictional soldiers, Vorenus and Pullo, continue as Vorenus makes a terrible decision after his wife's death in S1. The fortunes of four families continue to be followed as political and social situations arise across the city.  The power struggle between Servila and Atia and their families affects all of Rome and some of the known world at the time. There is one very unique character transformation as two actors play one role. All heading towards a monumental end with the depiction of the fate of two unlikely competitors and the ultimate winner of everything. Produced by William J. Macdonald, John Milius, and Bruno Heller. This is a forerunner of the "Game of Thrones" big-scale types of historical TV epics. Starring an outstanding cast of Kevin McKidd, Ray Stevenson, Simon Woods, Polly Walker, James Purefoy, Kerry Condon, Max Pirkis, Tobias Menzies, Indira Varma, Lindsay Duncan, and more. Carnality, profanity, violence. Four IMPERIAL Stars. (An HBO/ BBC production. Rated TV-MA. Color. HD. CC. X-Ray. 10-one hour episodes.)

Authentic, moving and great moral intelligence. Much, much better than any other historical drama about Rome that I have seen. Season 1 is amazing! For me, while it is not quite as miraculously good and powerful as 2001, Barry Lyndon, or In the Mood for Love (a few of my absolute all-time favorites), it is really only just a hair off. I am still surprised that something this good got made.

The sets are gorgeous. They also incorporate a great deal of scholarly details about Rome. Having been to Rome and being someone who is fascinated about ancient Rome, seeing the sets are a real treat.

The best choice made by the show (I assume it is the script writer's) is to focus on two ordinary Roman soldiers who are brave, reasonably good
and very relate-able.  The problem I have had with all the other Roman historical dramas is that the central, powerful characters are all really unsympathetic to me because they seem like power-mad bastards.  Probably they were a lot worse.  But even after the script writers have done their best to soft soap the central characters what was true is still detectable.  As a result I really couldn't care who gets whom and usually got bored stiff.

By placing Titus Pullo and Lucius Vorenus at the center, the show manages to go on with a big heart and a high level of moral intelligence.  That contrasts with the power struggles and makes the historical characters and goings-on more compelling.  I imagine that the director Michael Apted had a lot to do with the great sense of decency, that way of splitting the attention between the great and the little, without doing disservice to either,  that undergirds the show and makes it so wonderful.

** Spoiler**
One small example:  Julius Caesar asks the Egyptians to impale two heads of his enemies on the palace gate.  While a conventional show might have simply shown the heads on the spikes overlooking the gates to conclude the episode.  Michael Apted shows 5 Roman soldiers go outside the gate. Two climb onto the shoulders of two others who stand beneath them. The fifth then tosses the heads successively to the soldiers at the top, so that the heads can get impaled correctly.  All this is done in a practiced, matter-of-fact, "we do a good job come what may" fashion.  And it really makes you think... we think the powerful are what matters, but where would they be without the little guys, the soldiers, who actually do the head impaling and do it correctly?  What did the soldiers tell themselves about their day jobs.  Did they think it was fun? Or did they not like it because it takes forever to wash the blood off because the soap in Egypt is no good? Did they get trained in head paling?  It is just wonderful to be prompted to think about all these ordinary people who made the historical events possible.

P.S.
For me, the show worked best when it sticks close to the historical account.  I thought Octavia was the weakest character, because they essentially made her up.  But there was a real Octavia and she was utterly different from the show's depiction.  The historical Octavia (not Mark Anthony) had Cicero's hands, head and tongue pinned up on the senate house door because Cicero spoke out (and published speeches) against Anthony.  Once you know that, it is hard to accept the show's Octavia.  Atia appears to be a composite of other conniving Roman women described in the historical record, not the real Atia of whom we know next to nothing, so that worked okay for me.

The show, inexplicably to my mind, skips some very juicy historical details. For example, one historical source said that, during the 9 months or so Julius Caesar spent in Egypt, he was "every man's woman and every woman's man." (Caesar, being a patrician Roman, practiced Greek mores, which were considerably more relaxed than the stricter heterosexual mores of today.)  I would have enjoyed seeing a brief montage featuring the incomparable Ciara Hinds on this theme.  And I imagine it would have done wonders for the show's ratings.  Alas, nothing.

Another example, Octavius, or Caesar Augustus, was such a horrid thug during the civil wars that in one instance he plucked the eye balls out of one of his opponents.  I thought the show was foreshadowing this episode by showing the young Octavius beating a subdued enemy to death during episode 1.  But it seems to have ran out of time during season 2 and skipped that.  That left Octavius entirely too angelic looking.

Finally, some histories say the Roman legions sometimes marched while singing lurid and lewd songs about their Generals.  Sulla's soldiers marched while singing about Sulla having one testicle. (He in fact had two but allowed the song to show he had a sense of humor and was a good chap.)  Caesar's sang about his male (and female) sexual partners.  I always liked these stories.  To me, they explain a lot about how the Roman legions were so successful for so long. The soldiers were perfectly willing to die upon command, even commands they don't understand or agree with, but they were also totally at ease publicly making fun of their commander's personal life (not his competence to command). I understand one cannot show this kind of detail in a Hollywood movie or in an ABC show, but on HBO... that would have been perfect! Alas, nothing.

Mostly though, I just wish someone would restart the show, get the old team back, and let them make more of it.  Season 2 was too compressed.  There is a lot of Roman history. And I for one would be happy to pay to see all of it, both before and after the Gallic wars, if it is done by this team.

One of the great things about this TV show is that it's faithful to the actual historical facts of what happened in Ancient Rome, circa 1 A.D. Julius Ceasar's role as head of the Roman Republic is turned over to his odopted son (his nephew) Ocatavian Ceasar. You start to see the young Octavian (he's in his early 20's) mature into the Roman Emperor Augustus, the official name he took on later in his term as ruler of Rome. Excellent casting throughtout, in particular the beautiful but always scheming Attia (Octavian's mother). Several other characters that are very well portrayed are the Roman Centurian and the Roman soldier throught which we see most of the action. I recommend this televison show to anyone interested in Roman history and action dramas.

For a tv show, the series Rome was way above the usual tripe (as most of the Sunday night HBO shows have been). I found it interesting how the actor who played Julius Caesar (Ciaran Hinds, I think his name was) even looks like contemporary busts of the real Caesar.

They did play around with some facts for the series, but then again, it was a fictional series- still, it was about 90% accurate, so the producers did a pretty good job balancing history with entertainment. Besides, there's always some history geek like myself who'll quibble about that anyway, so they may as well give it a try.

The only thing I did not like in this series was how they handled Lucius Vorenus and his whole self loathing act and how it affected his ruling of the Palatine. It was a worthwhile sub plot to follow, but how it was presented just didn't feel real to me. I did like, however, how both the Vorenus and Pullo characters were named from Caesar's book on his conquest of Gaul: they were the only 2 legionnaires whose names were mentioned. Stuff like that makes this history geek warm all over.

So anyway, if you're interested in watching an entertaining series, Rome certainly maintained HBO's streak of excellent Sunday night viewing, and was even reasonably accurate historically as well. Vorenus may not have been believable during the second season, but it didn't lessen my appreciation of the overall story so much that I wouldn't recommend Rome as a show worth watching.

Second season of Rome takes more liberty with interpretation of historic events and characters than the first season. I am assuming that there is not a third season since Cesar has died, Antony and Brutus too. And, we can add Cleopatra and Cicero to the death lists. These deaths are all historic, but the character portrayals lacked conviction for me. Trying to update a 44BC character to the same ethos and pathos as someone today always doesn't work. In Season 2, for me, a history buff, it didn't work. Cleopatra and Anthony come off as the least believable for the time setting. Putting so many characters in black leathers to update their profiles was a bad idea. Creating street gangs in Rome allowing viewers to infer this time was the beginning of the Mafia is a big jump too. I continued to watch out of curiosity, but Season two did not work for me.
